A Fairy Tale
Once upon a time, in a distant land, there
was a magical, muddy kingdom called the
Hop. What a wonderful place the Hop was.
The creatures that lived at the Hop were
students, a strange variety of the species called man. Students took great pleasure in participating in many wonderful activities at the
Hop. They played lacrosse. They did
research. They slept. They played doctor.
But what the students liked to do most of
all was study.
So obsessed were the students with studying that they did practically nothing else.
They kept strange hours and grew attached
to the Hut, a room with a very high ceiling
and pretty windows. Students were also fond
of Uncle Miltie who had many books, both
new and old. One day, Uncle Miltie wanted
to give some books to the Hut. But the
students who liked the Hut didn't like what
Uncle Miltie wanted to do. So they got mad
for the first time in a good while.
But the students never cried. They didn't
cry when their Leader lied to them. She promised that she was going to make them
happy. She never did. Students never
respected her. They laughed at her.
But she stood tall. Or at least she tried.
Soon other students, with a little less power,
spoke against her. But she didn't give up.
She stood tall once again.
She made more and more promises, and
students became more and more unhappy.
They didn't like her anymore. And she probably didn't care.
It was to be her last year in the kingdom.
She sat back in her throne and laughed at
the other students. She said to her loyal
followers, "I can't believe they voted for me.
They must be stupid. Why else would they
have believed all of my promises? I can't
believe I pulled it off."
All right. That's enough with her. She'll
soon be forgotten. But what about next year.
We hope that students have learned
something from last year, that they'll be
smarter this time around and listen to what

The Albee Plays: Crackling Energy in the L/V Room
by Dan Vitale
Here it is, finally: Edward
Albee (yes, Edward Albee)
Directs Student Actors and
Technicians in Six Plays by Student Playwrights. The result is
what you might expect: works
of varying quality ably staged
and performed with varying
skill. The one constant is enthusiasm. An energy crackles
through these productions
which is barely containable on
the modest stage of the L/V
Room,so naturally, some of it
leaps out and fires the audience.
Which is as good a definition as
any of theater.
The entire production is
spread over two nights. It
previewed this past Tuesday
and Wednesday, and will be
and
tonight
repeated
tomorrow.
The first evening's program
consists of five short plays
separated by two intermissions.
First up is Kevin Sottak's Out
of Touch, a three-character
sketch about a college student
visiting his senescent grandparents. The play founders a
little on some overblown
language and has no resolution
to speak of, but it's buoyed by
good work from Rich Bigelow
as the grandfather.
Second is Change of Events
by Paul Murphy, a startling little blackout piece that gives new

meaning to the term "male fantasy." John Peng and Mark
Hughes contribute some lovely
business as drunks in a bar
where the pickup scene can get
pretty intense.
Sermon in Stone, by Bruce
Cohen, follows the first intermission. The author plays
Russell Jackalow, a high-school
senior whose emotional reaction to his father's death three
years before is preventing him
from planning his future, and
tearing him between two
substitute role models: an
English teacher and a television
comedian. The play is very insightful about such matters as
teacher/pupil relationships,
parental pride, and adolescent
idol worship, although again
the resolution could use a little
work. Deserving particular
praise here are Jim Sullivan,
who (with the help of Cohen's
flabbergastingly accurate
monologues) plays the comedian with just the right mix of
Vegas schmaltz and New York
hipness; and Katherine Hassler,
who, as Russell's mother, has
a wonderful scene in which she
gives her son a graduation gift.
After another intermission
come two plays, both of which
in their own ways are small
marvels. Steve Barthelme's
Clowns is about a couple whose
principal form of communication is the mindfuck, and it

contains some of the evening's
finest writing. The author is
wise to the ways in which our
perceptions of others are too
often warped by our own deficiencies as human beings. The
cast (Elizabeth Levy, Larry
Milgrim, Beth Polasky) play
the challenging roles in earnest,
but maybe a little too earnestly: their occasionally overdramatic readings tend to
dampen the naturalism of the
dialogue, and thus of the
situation.
The first evening concludes
with Joanne Hayden Coleman,
38, Suddenly, by Fae Dremock.
This simple piece about a man
whose stepsister's suicide drives
him to a grief something like
madness is a brooding, poetic
meditation on life and death,
given shape by some intriguing
blocking and anchored by the
powerful performance of Bruce
McKenzie.
The second night consists of
one full-length production, Inventory, by Jessica Kubzansky.
Hilary Freer is Margaret, a thirtyish antique dealer resigned to
the life of a spinster. Her
brother (Gregg Heacock), a
young executive, and sister
(Sam Murray), whose impending marriage forms the central
conflict of the play, serve as
contrast to Margaret's eventless
existence. Enter Merwin (Paul
Garlinghouse), local eccentric,

who seems to have taken it
upon himself to bring Margaret
joy and excitement—neither of
which she seems particularly interested in. Their odd intimacy
takes up most of the second
half of the play, creating a
chance for Margaret to touch
happiness. Will she take it?
Freer is a poignant Margaret,
particularly in a scene in which
it pains her even to look at her
sister's engagement ring. Garling house is pleasant as Merwin, and strong support is provided by Heacock (especially in
one powerful, alcohol-induced
outburst) and by Brad Powers
as Tim, Margaret's cynical yet
congenial shopboy.

Special mention must be
made of the fluid, nimble
lighting by Dan Press and
Reynerio Muradaz, and the excellent set designs by Ed Fisher,
who on the first night does
wonders with simple geometric
shapes and on the second turns
the stage into a fully stocked
antique shop. Commendations
also to the shadowy-costumed
backstage crew, whose contributions to the smooth, professional flow of these two
evenings should not be
underestimated.

five record.

seven and three. Finishing

The Albee Plays: Crackling Energy in the L/V Room
by Dan Vitale
Here it is, finally: Edward
Albee (yes, Edward Albee)
Directs Student Actors and
Technicians in Six Plays by Student Playwrights. The result is
what you might expect: works
of varying quality ably staged
and performed with varying
skill. The one constant is enthusiasm. An energy crackles
through these productions
which is barely containable on
the modest stage of the L/V
Room,so naturally, some of it
leaps out and fires the audience.
Which is as good a definition as
any of theater.
The entire production is
spread over two nights. It
previewed this past Tuesday
and Wednesday, and will be
and
tonight
repeated
tomorrow.
The first evening's program
consists of five short plays
separated by two intermissions.
First up is Kevin Sottak's Out
of Touch, a three-character
sketch about a college student
visiting his senescent grandparents. The play founders a
little on some overblown
language and has no resolution
to speak of, but it's buoyed by
good work from Rich Bigelow
as the grandfather.
Second is Change of Events
by Paul Murphy, a startling little blackout piece that gives new

meaning to the term "male fantasy." John Peng and Mark
Hughes contribute some lovely
business as drunks in a bar
where the pickup scene can get
pretty intense.
Sermon in Stone, by Bruce
Cohen, follows the first intermission. The author plays
Russell Jackalow, a high-school
senior whose emotional reaction to his father's death three
years before is preventing him
from planning his future, and
tearing him between two
substitute role models: an
English teacher and a television
comedian. The play is very insightful about such matters as
teacher/pupil relationships,
parental pride, and adolescent
idol worship, although again
the resolution could use a little
work. Deserving particular
praise here are Jim Sullivan,
who (with the help of Cohen's
flabbergastingly accurate
monologues) plays the comedian with just the right mix of
Vegas schmaltz and New York
hipness; and Katherine Hassler,
who, as Russell's mother, has
a wonderful scene in which she
gives her son a graduation gift.
After another intermission
come two plays, both of which
in their own ways are small
marvels. Steve Barthelme's
Clowns is about a couple whose
principal form of communication is the mindfuck, and it

contains some of the evening's
finest writing. The author is
wise to the ways in which our
perceptions of others are too
often warped by our own deficiencies as human beings. The
cast (Elizabeth Levy, Larry
Milgrim, Beth Polasky) play
the challenging roles in earnest,
but maybe a little too earnestly: their occasionally overdramatic readings tend to
dampen the naturalism of the
dialogue, and thus of the
situation.
The first evening concludes
with Joanne Hayden Coleman,
38, Suddenly, by Fae Dremock.
This simple piece about a man
whose stepsister's suicide drives
him to a grief something like
madness is a brooding, poetic
meditation on life and death,
given shape by some intriguing
blocking and anchored by the
powerful performance of Bruce
McKenzie.
The second night consists of
one full-length production, Inventory, by Jessica Kubzansky.
Hilary Freer is Margaret, a thirtyish antique dealer resigned to
the life of a spinster. Her
brother (Gregg Heacock), a
young executive, and sister
(Sam Murray), whose impending marriage forms the central
conflict of the play, serve as
contrast to Margaret's eventless
existence. Enter Merwin (Paul
Garlinghouse), local eccentric,

who seems to have taken it
upon himself to bring Margaret
joy and excitement—neither of
which she seems particularly interested in. Their odd intimacy
takes up most of the second
half of the play, creating a
chance for Margaret to touch
happiness. Will she take it?
Freer is a poignant Margaret,
particularly in a scene in which
it pains her even to look at her
sister's engagement ring. Garling house is pleasant as Merwin, and strong support is provided by Heacock (especially in
one powerful, alcohol-induced
outburst) and by Brad Powers
as Tim, Margaret's cynical yet
congenial shopboy.

Special mention must be
made of the fluid, nimble
lighting by Dan Press and
Reynerio Muradaz, and the excellent set designs by Ed Fisher,
who on the first night does
wonders with simple geometric
shapes and on the second turns
the stage into a fully stocked
antique shop. Commendations
also to the shadowy-costumed
backstage crew, whose contributions to the smooth, professional flow of these two
evenings should not be
underestimated.

The Blue Jay Swordsmen
have certainly got the world on

posted only a 2-3 mark within
the MAC.
The favorites were Haverford, the home school and
defending champions, and
Lafayette. Hopkins had lost to
both schools during the season.
But the Blue Jays had a game
plan and spent all week drilling
on the ways to beat the key men
from the other schools.
Jubilantly, they carried home
the result of their efforts, the
coveted Yale Cup.

is that they won the tournament; they didn't back into a
victory. Hopkins faced the two
top seeds in the first two
rounds. The Blue Jays then
proceeded to take eight of
twelve bouts from the favorites,
giving them a lead they relinquished only momentarily during the entire tournament.

Hopkins. The team took first
place by a comfortable six bout
margin over Lafayette College,
38-32. Stevens Tech followed in
third place.

the team met schools on a oneto-one basis, was a series of ups
and downs. Of the team's six

starters at the championship,
coach Richard Oles could only
be sure of the performances of
three. Of the others, he could
only hope.

place for the team and everyone
had a great day, putting
together the right combination
of tactics and moves to carry

Hopkins' fencing is unique
compared to most collegiate
programs, relying on little or no
recruiting. High school fencers
must contact the coach first

financial incentives to lure top
level prospects.
